Literature Review:
The evolution and evolvability of photosystem II have been a subject of intense research in the field of photosynthesis. Recent advances in our understanding of the origin and evolution of photosystem II have challenged and transformed current paradigms on the evolution of photosynthesis. The water-oxidizing and O2-evolving enzyme of photosynthesis, photosystem II, has remained virtually unchanged for billions of years, yet the nonstop duplication process of the D1 subunit of photosystem II has enabled the enzyme to become adaptable to variable environmental conditions and even to innovate enzymatic functions beyond water oxidation.

The evolution of photosystem II indicates that water oxidation originated early in the history of life, long before the diversification of cyanobacteria and other major groups of prokaryotes (1). This challenges the traditional view that photosynthesis evolved in cyanobacteria and was later adopted by other organisms (2). Instead, our analysis suggests that photosystem II arose independently in different lineages, highlighting the complexity and diversity of the evolutionary history of photosynthesis.

The D1 subunit of photosystem II is a critical component of the enzyme, controlling photochemistry and catalysis (3). The nonstop duplication process of the D1 subunit has enabled photosystem II to become adaptable to variable environmental conditions, such as changes in light intensity and temperature (4). This adaptability has allowed photosystem II to innovate enzymatic functions beyond water oxidation, such as the oxidation of other substrates (5).

The evolvability of photosystem II has significant implications for the development of novel light-powered enzymes with the capacity to carry out complex multistep oxidative transformations for sustainable biocatalysis (6). By harnessing the evolvability of photosystem II, researchers can design and engineer novel enzymes that can efficiently catalyze complex reactions, such as the oxidation of CO2 and the reduction of water (7).

Recent studies have also highlighted the importance of the PSII-D1 complex in regulating the activity of photosystem II (8). The PSII-D1 complex is composed of the photosystem II core complex and the D1 subunit, and plays a critical role in controlling the photochemical and catalytic activities of photosystem II (9). Mutations in the D1 subunit have been shown to affect the activity of photosystem II, highlighting the importance of this subunit in regulating the enzyme's function (10).

In conclusion, the evolution and evolvability of photosystem II have significant implications for our understanding of the origin and evolution of photosynthesis. The nonstop duplication process of the D1 subunit has enabled photosystem II to become adaptable to variable environmental conditions and to innovate enzymatic functions beyond water oxidation. By harnessing the evolvability of photosystem II, researchers can design and engineer novel enzymes with the capacity to carry out complex multistep oxidative transformations for sustainable biocatalysis.
